description: Basic test case: isomorphic strings with a simple mapping.
expectedBehavior: Should return true because 'egg' and 'add' have a direct mapping: e->a, g->d.

description: Basic test case: non-isomorphic strings where one character maps to two different characters.
expectedBehavior: Should return false because 'foo' and 'bar' cannot be isomorphic: f->b, o->a, o->r (o maps to both a and r).

description: Basic test case: isomorphic strings with character mapping to itself.
expectedBehavior: Should return true because 'paper' and 'title' are isomorphic: p->t, a->i, e->l, r->e.
Should return true because empty strings are isomorphic by definition.
Should return true because single-character strings are always isomorphic to each other.

description: Edge case: strings of different lengths.
expectedBehavior: Should return false because strings of different lengths cannot be isomorphic.

description: Complex case: strings with repeating patterns that are isomorphic.
expectedBehavior: Should return true because the repeating patterns maintain a consistent mapping.

description: Complex case: strings where one string has repeating characters and the other doesn't, making them non-isomorphic.
expectedBehavior: Should return false because the repeating characters in one string must map to repeating characters in the other.

description: Complex case: Long strings that are isomorphic.
expectedBehavior: Should return true because the mapping is consistently applied across the entire strings.

description: Complex case: strings with some identical characters but ultimately not isomorphic.
expectedBehavior: Should return false because the mapping rule is eventually violated.

description: Edge case: strings where all characters are the same.
expectedBehavior: Should return true because all characters can map to the same character.

description: Complex case: near isomorphic strings that differ only in one character mapping.
expectedBehavior: Should return false as one character mapping differs.
